Patient: Hello? 

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from Sheba Medical Center on a recorded line. Is this Alicia Daniels? 

 Patient: Yes. It is. 

 Nurse: Great, I'm calling on behalf of Dr. Robert Friedman, your Cardiologist. -- To protect your privacy, can you please share your date of birth? 

 Patient: Sure. It's January the first nineteen sixty. 

 Nurse: Thanks for confirming that. I'm your AI Post-Discharge Specialist. Dr. Friedman asked me to check in on you after your discharge from the hospital. How are you doing today? 

 Patient: I'm actually doing very well. Thank you. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. Being back home must be a relief after your hospital stay. Is there anything specific you're looking forward to doing? 

 Patient: Nothing really specific. I want us to try to catch up on my sleep. I want to spend sometime with my husband. I just wanna get back to normal. 

 Nurse: Catching up on sleep and spending time with your husband sounds like a wonderful plan. How long have you two been married? 

 Patient: Oh, my goodness. We have been married for forty years. 

 Nurse: Wow, forty years! That's quite a milestone. I'm sure your husband is glad to have you back home. I'm calling to check on how you're doing with your new medications. Do you have any questions or concerns you'd like to address before we go over them? 

 Patient: No. Not yet. 

 Nurse: Okay then. Let's start with your new prescription, Omepradex 20 mg capsule. Have you been able to pick it up from the pharmacy? 

 Patient: Oh, my products. Yeah. I've got it. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. Are you taking the Omepradex 20 mg capsule two times a day as prescribed? 

 Patient: I am. 

 Nurse: That's excellent. Sticking to the prescribed schedule helps manage your stomach ulcers effectively. Let's move on to your existing medications. Are you still taking Advil and Cymbalta? 

 Patient: I am taking both of those. Yes. 

 Nurse: I appreciate your diligence in taking your medications. However, I need to clarify something. Advil, which is a type of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, can sometimes worsen stomach ulcers. Have you noticed any increase in your symptoms since you've been taking it? 

 Patient: No. I have it. But I'm supposed to take it when I need it, and I haven't needed it. So I really haven't been taking it. 

 Nurse: That's a wise decision, especially considering your stomach ulcers. If you do experience pain, it would be better to opt for a different pain reliever that's safer for your condition. I'll make a note for your doctor about this. Moving on, do you ever have trouble remembering to take your medications on time? 

 Patient: No. No. I don't have that money to take, so I don't have a problem. 

 Nurse: That's excellent to hear. Keeping up with your medication schedule is key to managing your health. Since you've been discharged, have you noticed any new health concerns or changes in your condition? 

 Patient: No. I don't think so. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. If you do notice any changes, don't hesitate to reach out to us at Sheba Medical Center. Do you have any other questions or concerns about your medications or anything else? 

 Patient: Will be omepradex. Patient: Am I supposed to wait to eat? After taking it, or do I eat right away? I'm a little bit confused. 

 Nurse: Omepradex is most effective when taken on an empty stomach, about an hour before a meal. This allows the medication to be fully absorbed before food enters your stomach. 

 Patient: Okay. So what I'm hearing is you take the omepradex. Patient: And then you wait for an hour. And then you each. Am I getting that correct? 

 Nurse: Yes, that's correct. Take the Omepradex, wait for about an hour, and then you can eat. This helps the medication work effectively. Is there anything else you'd like to know? 

 Patient: Don't think so. 


 


 Nurse: Okay. To summarize, you're doing well with your medications, and you'll continue taking Omepradex as prescribed, about an hour before meals. You'll avoid taking Advil due to your stomach ulcers. I'll inform Doctor Friedman about our conversation. Thank you for your time, Ms. Daniels. Remember, if you need anything, reach out to Sheba Medical Center. Enjoy catching up on your sleep and spending time with your husband. 

 Patient: Thank you very much.
